summary: Paul Merson, a Sky Sports pundit, criticized Tottenham midfielder Andros Townsend for being brought on late in a match against Burnley, continuing a previous dispute. Merson had earlier questioned Townsend's inclusion in the England squad. Townsend scored a goal for England against Italy, prompting Merson to admit he was wrong about Townsend. Townsend responded to Merson's criticism on Twitter. Despite the initial tension, Merson resumed his criticism after Tottenham's draw with Burnley.

Chelsea has made an offer for 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto from FC Tokyo. Muto, a Japan international, is expected to join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if the move to Chelsea is completed. The £4 million deal is not connected to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has 37 appearances and 16 goals for FC Tokyo, and 11 international caps with 1 goal for Japan. He has scored three goals in four games this season.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The study, published in the journal Pediatrics, suggests that antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic, similar to their use in farm animals to promote weight gain. Key findings include:

- By age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese.
- Repeated antibiotic prescriptions before age two increased the likelihood of being overweight.
- Boys were particularly prone to weight gain after antibiotic use and were slightly taller than those who hadn't been given the drugs.
- The study did not prove causality but suggested that antibiotics might alter gut bacteria, leading to increased food availability and appetite.
- The lead author, Dr. Antti Saari, emphasized the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy to mitigate potential contributions to the childhood obesity epidemic.
- Previous research has linked early antibiotic use to higher risks of eczema and digestive problems.
- There are growing concerns about antibiotic over-prescription leading to antibiotic resistance and harder-to-treat infections.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, dropping his rifle and knocking his bearskin hat. The incident was captured on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell, and occurred in front of hundreds of spectators. The guard quickly got up and continued his duties while his colleagues marched past. The fall is believed to have been caused by metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a popular tourist attraction at Buckingham Palace.

The passage discusses the remake of the iconic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and had over 100 million viewers. The remake, set to air in 2016, will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. LeVar Burton, who played the lead role in the original, will co-executive produce the new version. The remake aims to be more authentic, drawing from Alex Haley's novel and consulting historians. The new generation of viewers will experience the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery, in a contemporary context.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978, palace aides tried to force him into an orgy. He was pinned to a chair and groped by a male member of staff. Lawler left the job immediately and only reported the incident to palace officials last year, after inquiries into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s began. His initial complaints were ignored for months before the police were notified. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with the ongoing police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme from 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, filmed while driving, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the video, they humorously recount their journey to parenthood, including the quick conception and their friends' and family's reactions. The video ends with them sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple made the video to share the news with distant loved ones. The video's success was unexpected, and they are considering making another video after finding out the gender of the child.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at an auction in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray, was featured in several key scenes, including encounters with Rhett Butler (Clark Gable) and an attack in a shanty town. The dress was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film, owned by James Tumblin, former head of the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Gable for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary the previous year.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The incident occurred around 3 PM on Saturday. The boy's mother was holding him and another child when he slipped and fell 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The parents rescued the child before emergency services arrived. The boy suffered minor injuries, including bumps, bruises, and a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs. He was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center and listed in stable condition. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Birmingham, which has been non-functional for over two years, has been turned to face a residential house. Around 300 similar cameras were decommissioned in 2013 due to outdated technology. The council is aware of the incident and plans to address it, but the camera will not be part of a new pilot program using digital technology. The homeowners could not be reached for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt expressed his excitement and readiness for the event, highlighting Jamaica's strong relay tradition. The Jamaican Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) is pleased to have Bolt on the team, and the full team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, showed their support for the club's basketball team by attending an El Clasico match against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Neymar also captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile in a recent international match. Barcelona is currently competing for a treble of trophies, including La Liga, where they are four points clear at the top. Neymar and his teammates will next face Celta Vigo in La Liga.

Italy is currently dealing with a significant influx of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. Between Friday and Monday, the Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants and received SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. There are concerns that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship reportedly capsized, but the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. There has been a recent increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in Italy in the first three months of 2015, and about 2,000 rescued at sea during the first weekend of April. Most migrants are from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels, with some captains abandoning their ships.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool. Sanchez, who had multiple elite club options, was convinced to continue his career under Wenger and has since made an instant impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities, efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit, believing he revitalizes the team and supporters. Wenger also commends Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for his team's development despite key player losses. Wenger has downplayed rumors of a potential move for Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record, set by Australian Rohan Dennis, is 52.491km. Wiggins, who recently finished his Team Sky career, aims to motivate others to challenge themselves and hopes for a capacity crowd of 6,000 to support his attempt. Tickets for the event go on sale on April 19.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, found her match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup challenging, despite ultimately winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3. Williams admitted the match was an "eye-opener" regarding her preparedness for the claycourt season. The U.S. team lost 3-2 to Italy, with Williams and Alison Riske losing the doubles match 6-0, 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the U.S. being relegated to World Group II. Williams acknowledged she needs to adapt her game for clay courts and be prepared for longer rallies. The U.S. team will need to work harder to return to the elite nations next year.

River Plate is interested in signing Radamel Falcao from Manchester United. Falcao, a Colombian forward, previously played for River Plate from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's interest in Falcao, stating that they "dream of Falcao" and that "the doors are open." However, the deal is complicated due to Falcao's current loan situation at Manchester United, where he has scored only four Premier League goals this season. Falcao has been in good form for Colombia, recently equaling the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, known for her vocals and long hair, became the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles against a city background, promoting Batiste dry shampoo. The partnership, facilitated by the MILES agency, launched with a TV ad featuring Henderson's single "Mirror Man." Henderson and her management expressed excitement about the collaboration.

A man, Aaron Siler, was shot dead by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, on March 14. Siler was wanted on a felony warrant and was armed during a vehicle and foot pursuit. Torres, who is on leave pending the investigation, is featured on a billboard erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanking the community for its support. Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful and are calling for its removal. The police association maintains that no offense was intended. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in a clash with militants near the Pakistan border in the southeastern town of Negur. Three militants were also killed. The militants, reportedly from the group Jaish al Adal, crossed into Iran from Pakistan. Jaish al Adal, a Sunni Muslim group, has targeted Shiites and aims to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian authorities have asked Pakistan to apprehend the surviving assailants. Pakistan has condemned the attack and is investigating.

The passage discusses a political discussion in Japan regarding real-life "Space Invaders" and UFOs. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani assured that Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. This discussion was prompted by a question from former wrestler and lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who has a history of unique political and public engagements. Inoki had asked if aircraft were scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. The exchange highlights Japan's consideration of potential extraterrestrial threats, with a previous defense minister having discussed the legal implications of defending against an invasion from outer space.

A passenger, Jin Pai, was injured at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport when a toilet he was squatting on broke, causing deep cuts to his leg and buttocks. He was hospitalised and received several stitches. The incident occurred because he was worried about the cleanliness of the seat. He initially called his companions for help but was too injured to wait for them and was taken to the hospital. Authorities consider the incident an accident and reminded people to use toilets as intended.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a girl in her home over four years and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The investigation started when a 15-year-old girl found the hidden camera in her bathroom. Rebbie is charged with aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. He admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and specifically targeted the 15-year-old victim. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series, titled "Daughter and Salaryman," features photographs of teenage daughters standing calmly while their fathers perform dramatic jumps in the background. The daughters are dressed casually and look directly into the camera, smiling, while their fathers, dressed in suits, pull energetic poses. Some of the fathers appear to be in pain due to the effort of the jumps. The photographs are set in front of various Japanese landmarks and have garnered significant online interest due to their unusual nature. The series aims to show the fun side of fathers, who are usually seen as serious.

The passage discusses the start of the county championship season in English cricket and the potential return of Kevin Pietersen to the England team. Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has opened the possibility for Pietersen's return, despite his controversial axing in 2014. Pietersen, now 34, is playing for Surrey and is hopeful of regaining a spot in the England Test set-up. The passage also mentions the upcoming matches for Surrey and Pietersen's varied emotions during a team photo shoot at the KIA Oval.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has dismissed coach Ze Maria after a poor run of results. Ze Maria, a former Brazilian defender, was initially fired and then reinstated by the club's owner, Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, Ze Maria was sacked again. The club is currently in 16th place, six points from safety. Ze Maria, who had 25 international caps for Brazil, will be replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao, a former Monaco player, has had a challenging season-long loan at Manchester United, failing to reach his previous performance levels post-knee injury. He has scored only four goals. His former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, suggests that Falcao might regret leaving Monaco, where he was unhappy but would have played in the Champions League. Manchester United is unlikely to make Falcao's transfer permanent due to his poor performance.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy, making off with about $1500 in cash. The tall offender was captured on security footage demanding cash from the owner's daughter. Police are seeking public help to identify the man, who remains at large. There were no reported weapons used in the robbery.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice in March 2023. The first arrest was for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, where she admitted to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts. The second arrest came after another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January 2023. Both incidents involved students from the same high school. Granado was released on bail after both arrests. The school district placed her on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being present on school property.

A video of a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times online. The incident was witnessed by tourist Tim Weston, who described the crocodile holding onto the dog for hours. The dog belonged to a local bike shop owner and was curious about the crocodile. The marina is near a crocodile sanctuary, and crocodiles are common in the area due to the mangroves and urbanization. Social media users reacted with horror to the video.

Steve Bruce, Hull City's manager, is determined to keep the team in the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton. Hull has six wins and needs to secure eight or nine wins to avoid relegation. They have six games left, including challenging matches against top teams. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players. Southampton won with a penalty from James Ward-Prowse and a late goal from Graziano Pelle. Southampton's manager, Ronald Koeman, had to address an issue with Sadio Mane trying to take the penalty instead of Ward-Prowse.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers and altered some answers himself, invalidating his school's SATs results. This incident occurred at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. The Department for Education annulled the entire school's SATs results for 2014 following an investigation. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted that his conduct was unacceptable. The panel acknowledged his remorse but emphasized that his actions, though not fraudulent, were dishonest and had a serious impact on the school.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has had limited playing time but enjoys a happy personal life. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year, and they have a son together. Lindegaard has been with United since 2010 but has made only 19 league appearances. He is currently third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite his lack of playing time, Lindegaard has a strong social media presence and often shares photos with his wife.

The passage discusses the unsuccessful auction of the iconic blue letters that once hung over Yankee Stadium. The 13 letters, which were expected to sell for $300,000 to $600,000, received no bids at a Sotheby's auction. The letters, which are 10 feet tall and wide, were purchased by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson had hoped a new generation would own and enjoy this icon of the Yankees and of New York City. The letters had been installed in 1976 and taken down in 2008. Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their recent behavior, which included Sterling inhaling nitrous oxide and both players being photographed with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to them about their professional responsibilities but decided not to discipline them. He wants to move past the incident. Rodgers is focusing on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Steven Gerrard available after serving a suspension. Despite recent setbacks, Rodgers believes the team is ready to progress.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and shared a picture of himself relaxing with his dog. He performed well for Germany in a Euro 2016 qualifier against Georgia. Ozil is expected to start in Arsenal's upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. He has been in good form since returning from injury, contributing four assists and three goals. Ozil mentioned that he is adjusting well to English football, appreciating the frequent matches.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club is satisfied with Luis Enrique's performance and has no plans to replace him. Enrique, who took charge last summer and has a contract until 2016, is six games away from potentially winning the La Liga title. Bartomeu praised Enrique's dedication and the team's potential to win three trophies this season. In their recent match, Barcelona defeated Valencia 2-0, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract worth around £100,000-a-week, running until 2020. This deal comes after Henderson's impressive performance this season, contributing 13 assists and seven goals. He is expected to replace Steven Gerrard as Liverpool captain. Henderson is the third key player, after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, to extend his contract under manager Brendan Rodgers.

Filipe Luis, a Chelsea player, wants to stay at the club until the end of his three-year contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. He has faced competition for the left back position at Chelsea. Luis has played for Brazil in recent friendlies and is now focused on Chelsea's Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is pushing the team to remain focused and win every game.

Nathan Hughes' three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal. Hughes, a Wasps No 8, was initially suspended for a knee-to-head collision during a match on March 27, which left North unconscious and required stretcher removal. Despite no intent, Hughes received a sanction. The appeal, supported by Wasps and other critics, argued the incident was accidental. The appeal panel agreed, rescinding the ban and allowing Hughes to return to action immediately. However, he is not expected to play until April 26.

A fiery sunset was observed in Washington, caused by smoke from wildfires in Siberia. The fires, started by farmers, spread due to strong winds and destroyed dozens of villages. Smoke from these fires was carried by winds across the Pacific Ocean, reaching the Pacific Northwest. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, resulting in intense red sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was recovered with cosmetic changes, including red rims, red detailing, and an orange steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves on Facebook for the modifications. She is now having the car professionally cleaned to remove strong odors and has created a smoothie at her restaurant to honor the man who helped locate her car.

Manchester City players, including Sergio Aguero, Yaya Toure, David Silva, Joe Hart, and James Milner, stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club uses incentivised contracts to comply with financial fair play rules, with around £12 million in bonuses at stake. Currently in fourth place, City faces a challenging schedule and must avoid finishing fifth to secure Champions League qualification. The team has struggled recently, losing seven times since January, including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged the team's poor form. Rivals Manchester United, who recently defeated City, are confident about signing top players like Paul Pogba.

The passage describes a youth football match between Manchester United and Manchester City's Under 18 teams, dubbed a'mini-derby'. Key points include:

- The match took place at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with free entry and around 1,000 spectators.
- Manchester United won 1-0, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal from a free-kick.
- The match featured a high number of English and local players.
- Both teams showed skill and commitment, with several notable performances.
- The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough in the league, while City has lost both of their end-of-season play-off matches.
- The match highlighted the potential of homegrown talents.

Joe Hart, an England goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon, an Italian goalkeeper, calling him a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who earned his 50th cap for England, expressed his admiration for Buffon's career and skill, and his desire to continue learning and playing for his club and country.

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant chain, has partnered with the Postmates app to enter the $70 billion food delivery market. They will offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, with a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. This move comes after Chipotle previously declined offers from third-party delivery services. The chain has seen recent popularity, with presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton visiting their restaurants. Other food franchises, such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, are also exploring delivery services.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Bill and Denise Richard, have publicly pleaded to remove the death penalty for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. Their son, Martin, was killed, and their daughter, Jane, was severely injured in the 2013 attack. The Richards, who have endured immense suffering, argue that pursuing the death penalty could prolong their pain through years of appeals. They urge the Justice Department to sentence Tsarnaev to life in prison without the possibility of release and to waive all rights to appeal. The sentencing phase of Tsarnaev's trial begins on Tuesday and is expected to last four weeks.

A Boeing 747 jumbo jet has been converted into a luxury home for a billionaire, costing approximately £400 million. The custom-built plane, originally designed to carry 600 passengers, now features multiple bedrooms, lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, and an onboard restaurant. It includes a'state room,' an 'aeroloft' with eight beds, a conference room, and various relaxation areas. The plane can accommodate dozens of guests and is one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS) from Cape Canaveral, Florida. The rocket's first stage attempted to land on a floating barge but tipped over after a hard landing. This was the second attempt to land on a drone ship, following a previous failure in January. SpaceX aims to reduce spaceflight costs by reusing rockets. The Dragon spacecraft successfully docked with the ISS to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker. After about five weeks, Dragon will return to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of cargo. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at a new chapel in Las Vegas, Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel, located at the Westgate Hotel. The wedding is part of a contest run by NBC's Today show for an Elvis-obsessed couple, with the winners announced on the following Monday and the wedding taking place on April 23. The winning couple will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla Presley has been involved in the chapel's design, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Couples had to submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season in a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. Liverpool is four points behind Manchester City. Raheem Sterling scored the first goal in the ninth minute, and Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal with 20 minutes left.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak by defeating Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute from a counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves to secure the win. Roma moved four points ahead of Lazio and ended a seven-match home winless streak. Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches and remained fifth. The match had heightened security due to past incidents. Roma was without key players Francesco Totti and Gervinho.

Doncaster Rovers, a League One team, has had a lackluster season, currently in mid-table. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town ended in a 0-0 draw, which was low on excitement. The match highlights, posted on the club's YouTube channel, were notably short, lasting only 27 seconds with 14 seconds of actual match action, including the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

The passage describes a unique relationship between a man, Roland Giroux, and his pet blood parrot cichlid. The fish, a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, was bred in Taiwan around 1986. Giroux interacts with the fish by gently massaging it and stroking it with his fingers, with the fish appearing to enjoy the sensation and returning to his hand for more. The fish was initially bullied by tank mates, but Giroux removed them and began hand-feeding the fish, which increased its sociability. The fish becomes frustrated if not played with daily and will follow Giroux's hand to the surface when he removes it from the tank.

Ben Stokes, a fiery character in the England cricket team, is known for his aggressive behavior, such as punching a locker after being dismissed and clashing with Marlon Samuels. Despite these incidents, Stokes is valued for his character and potential to bring runs and wickets to the team. England coach Peter Moores has helped Stokes manage his aggression, and the team wants to nurture his talent while controlling his behavior. Stokes' inclusion in the team is prioritized over playing two spinners, as England aims to develop his skills further.

The passage discusses a Euro 2016 qualifier match between Wales and Belgium. Key points include:

- The match, scheduled for June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium, is a sell-out with 33,000 tickets sold.
- Both teams are tied on points, but Belgium leads due to a better goal difference.
- Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has boosted their qualification hopes.
- The match will be played at Cardiff City Stadium due to player preference and UEFA rules, despite speculation about using the larger Millennium Stadium.
- This qualifier is significant as Wales is in their best position to qualify for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup.

England's Under-17 team, coached by John Peacock, will defend their UEFA European Under-17 Championship title in Bulgaria. They are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, with notable inclusions being Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, and Arsenal's Chris Willock, who is called up for the first time. The team qualified for the finals with a perfect record, beating Romania, Norway, and Slovenia in the Elite Round. Their other group matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis from Anderlecht. The teenager is highly regarded and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his studies. Manchester City has been in talks with Anderlecht's chairman to agree on a compensation package, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure the young talent for the club's future.

A man has been arrested and later bailed in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort. Santillan was found strangled and beaten in a flat in Fulham, south west London, on March 28. She had moved to London from Mexico and worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami. Police are investigating the circumstances surrounding her death and appealing for information from anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death.

Dawn, a woman who experienced seven miscarriages, discovered that £207 she had saved for her baby's gravestone was stolen by a family friend, Jamie. Dawn confronted Jamie and his girlfriend Carol, who initially denied the theft. A lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show revealed Jamie's guilt. Dawn was devastated and stormed off the stage in tears. Jamie had previously sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to the theft but blamed his girlfriend.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a persecuted minority group, in northern Iraq. The release, coordinated by Arab tribal leaders, included mostly women, children, and the elderly or ill. The exact number of released individuals varies between 217 and 228. ISIS had previously released other Yazidis, largely children and the elderly. The Yazidis, of Kurdish descent with a pre-Islamic religion, have faced historic persecution, including recent atrocities by ISIS. The Yazidi crisis began when ISIS took over their towns, leading to a humanitarian crisis and international intervention.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham striker, has had a remarkable season, breaking into the first team and England's side. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animation featuring Kane's best goals and celebrations has been released by Copa90, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?'. The video highlights his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle, a long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. Kane is up against Chelsea's Eden Hazard and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez for the PFA Player of the Year award.

Jamie Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, has expressed his support for Brendan Rodgers to continue as Liverpool's manager despite the team's recent lack of trophies and potential miss of Champions League qualification. Carragher believes that Rodgers' future should not be determined by a single game and that the team has the potential to improve with the right signings. He also highlighted the importance of community work, for which he received a Beacon Award.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic Nerf toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security concerns. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was deemed a security risk when detected by X-ray machines. Airport security officers performed a pat-down on James and took the toy. His father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security checks as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous." The family proceeded to their flight to Lanzarote without the toy. Upon returning, James received a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and offered to return the toy but defended their actions as following government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited items, such as replica or model guns.

A man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend/wife. He listed specific requirements for his dream girl, including being a non-drinker, non-smoker, fit, attractive, good with pets, reliable, honest, loyal, and skilled in various domestic tasks. He described himself as athletic, tattooed, and successful, with a love for the outdoors and various hobbies. Rich offered benefits such as a company car, phone, laptop, and gym membership to the successful candidate. He also mentioned he is not shy about spending money on his partner and is open to reasonable offers. Former partners are not encouraged to apply.

Greg Dyke, the Football Association chairman, is seeking to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and change the definition of 'home-grown' to include players who have trained in England for three years before the age of 18. He faces opposition from the Premier League but has the support of five former England managers: Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren. These managers warn that blocking Dyke's proposals could hinder England's chances of winning the World Cup and further reduce the pool of English talent at the top level. They highlight the emergence of young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane but express concern about the lack of opportunities for these players.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, has given birth to a baby daughter in the TV show Poldark. The episode will show Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, with his new baby. The timeline of Demelza's pregnancy is questioned by fans, as she goes from announcing her pregnancy to giving birth in a short period. Fans have also noticed the quick progression of pregnancies in the show.

Leicester City, currently bottom of the Premier League table but with a slim chance of survival, has won two consecutive games, including a 3-2 victory at West Brom thanks to Jamie Vardy's injury-time goal. Manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus on their own games and not get distracted by their relegation rivals. Pearson emphasizes that Leicester's future is in their own hands and that they should concentrate on their remaining matches to secure a realistic chance of survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a record for the longest mammal migration, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. The whale's route included three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting that Varvara might be an eastern gray whale rather than the endangered western gray whale, which could imply that the population of western gray whales is even smaller than previously thought.

A section of seabed, approximately 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide, rose up to 50 feet above sea level overnight on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido Island, Japan. Geologists attribute this phenomenon to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which pivoted the underwater area upward. Local residents were unaware of any tremors or sounds during the event. The new landmass, which still bears marine organisms, is not expected to expand further and is not believed to be related to a recent earthquake in Nepal.

Gregory van der Wiel, a Paris Saint-Germain player, has denied rumors of leaving the club this summer. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc, Van der Wiel expressed his happiness at PSG and his desire to stay. He is open to signing a new contract and is ready to play whenever called upon. However, PSG's interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves may impact Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez, a striker for Juventus, has expressed his desire to leave the club this summer to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. His contract with Juventus expires at the end of next season, but he wants to leave earlier. Boca Juniors has confirmed they are close to completing a deal for Tevez, but he must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Tevez joined Boca's youth academy in 1996 and has always intended to finish his career there. Juventus is reluctant to lose their top scorer, who has netted 17 goals this season, but has accepted his decision to leave.

During a Champions League match, Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski. This victory secured Bayern's place in the semi-finals. Notably, Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, tore his trousers during the match, briefly exposing his underwear. Despite Porto's 2-goal lead from the first leg, Bayern's performance was dominant.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in injuries to all occupants. Two adults and two children were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, while six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital. One person was trapped and rescued by Queensland Fire and Rescue. The highway was closed for a few hours with diversions in place.

Arsenal, currently second in the Premier League, will host league leaders Chelsea this weekend. Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil has received a new Apple Watch, which he compared to Michael Knight's watch from the TV show Knight Rider. Ozil is expected to start in the upcoming match against Chelsea. Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games remaining. Jack Wilshere, who has returned from injury, is seen as a key player for Arsenal's future, but his fitness record is a concern.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford. He has sent off three players from both United and City this season, including City captain Vincent Kompany. Clattenburg has shown only two red cards this season, both to United players. The match is crucial as United and City are closely ranked, with United having won their last five consecutive league games and City struggling since the turn of the year.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of assuming that embattled MP Billy Gordon would quit after being accused of domestic violence and withholding his criminal history, using the phrase "a little black puppet on a string." Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, sympathized with Gordon's position and defended his statement, saying he used the term "black puppet" in light of his personal experiences. Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party but will remain in the Queensland parliament as an independent. Katter's statement sparked criticism on social media, with users questioning his terminology.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, born with cerebral palsy, is using dance videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. Despite facing bullying and stares, she aims to change how people with disabilities are represented in media and to encourage others not to judge based on appearances. Dayna's videos, including one set to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," showcase her dancing abilities and her message that she is similar to everyone else despite her disability. She has also taken up motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, coached by Adrian Heath, has expressed interest in signing Javier Hernandez from Manchester United. Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan spell at Real Madrid, is also being pursued by eight European clubs. Orlando City has a large Latin-American fanbase and is captained by Kaka. Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from several European clubs if he does not agree to terms at United.

A group of at least three individuals set fire to a white Dodge Charger at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning. The driver had an argument with the suspects while pumping gas, and the suspects attempted to carjack him. The car was completely destroyed, but the driver and two passengers escaped unharmed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson.

A chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He admitted to these misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these allegations, Manuel received outstanding patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. The circumstances surrounding his license revocation, including the bartering of sex for services and recommending patients stop taking prescribed medication, must be resolved before he can resume practicing.

A Russian fighter jet intercepted a U.S. reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. crew reported aggressive maneuvers by the Russian SU-27 Flanker. The Russian Defense Ministry claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off, which the U.S. denied. The U.S. will file a complaint through diplomatic channels. This is not the first such incident; a similar close encounter occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City. The theft occurred overnight on March 27, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was taken after the thief broke the car's rear window and used a rope and another vehicle to pull the case free. Other items, including a gear bag and clothing, were also stolen but have since been recovered. The rifle has not been found. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and it is unclear if the agent's car was specifically targeted. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer.

In July 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in Canberra. Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the incident. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and suggested that Costa's mental state was declining leading up to and during the event. Costa's mental state is crucial to the case, as a not guilty verdict could be returned if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack is proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley after he missed a penalty in a 1-0 win against Burnley. Barkley took the penalty in the 10th minute, despite Leighton Baines' proven success rate from the spot. Martinez stated that any of the three or four designated penalty takers could take the kick based on how they felt at the moment. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but it did not affect the outcome as Kevin Mirallas scored the only goal of the game.

Two passengers were found dead in their cabin on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, with initial indications suggesting a murder-suicide. The incident occurred at 11:30 a.m. on Thursday, and the ship's authorities, including the FBI, are investigating. The ship is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and had departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise. The bodies were discovered by the cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin's door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced by drawing 2-2 with Montserrat in the second leg, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team had previously won 2-1 in the first leg. Curacao will next face Cuba in the qualifying round. Kluivert's mother is from Curacao, and he has World Cup experience as both a player and an assistant coach.

Esteban Cambiasso, a veteran midfielder with a decorated career, including 15 trophies at Inter Milan, has joined Leicester City and is determined to help the team stay in the Premier League. Despite Leicester being seven points from safety with eight games left, Cambiasso believes that keeping them up would be as rewarding as winning a trophy. He acknowledges the challenge but remains confident in the team's ability to secure the necessary points. Cambiasso, who has quickly become a key player since joining in the summer, is happy in Leicester and could extend his stay beyond his current one-year contract.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her two children under five due to her excessive drinking, partying, and suspected theft. Her mother, Debbie, who has been caring for the children since they were four months old, has expressed concerns about Gemma's lifestyle and her ability to care for the children. Debbie has threatened to ban Gemma from seeing the children after discovering her use of legal highs and suspicion of theft. Gemma admits to past thefts but denies stealing an iPad from one of the children. Debbie plans to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children due to trust issues.

During a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Eden Hazard scored a goal for Chelsea. However, Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed that there was a foul by Chelsea's John Terry on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao in the build-up to the goal. Terry's strong challenge from behind on Falcao was deemed a foul by the pundits, who felt that play should have been stopped. The goal was scored after Cesc Fabregas collected the loose ball from Terry's challenge, passed it to Oscar, and Hazard scored.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway. Everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out. The bus was carrying Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver. The band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. The fire destroyed most of the bus's contents, except for Scott's Bible. The incident occurred on Interstate 30, northeast of Dallas. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing space lasers to convert sunlight into energy and beam it back to Earth to power homes. This technology could make solar power viable in Scotland and provide instant power to disaster-hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and further testing is planned in Portugal. The lasers are not powerful enough to be used as weapons, unlike those depicted in science fiction. The technology is different from a proposed laser system for the International Space Station aimed at clearing space debris.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, has escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen at 6:15 pm on Tuesday and is described as about 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, with dark hair, and possibly without his beard. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He was convicted of this offense and others involving indecent images of children. Police are urgently seeking information on his whereabouts.

The passage discusses a legal case involving Donald Sterling, former owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, and his former companion, V. Stiviano. Key points include:

- A Los Angeles judge ordered Stiviano to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts to Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling.
- The lawsuit accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and receiving expensive gifts from Donald Sterling, including luxury cars and a duplex.
- Stiviano defended the gifts, stating there was nothing wrong with receiving them.
- The court decision was seen as a victory for the Sterling family.
- Donald Sterling's racist remarks, captured in an audio recording with Stiviano, led to his ban from the NBA and the termination of his ownership rights in the Clippers.

Thierry Henry, a former Arsenal player and current Sky Sports pundit, has criticized Arsenal's transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four key players: a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker. He believes these signings are crucial for Arsenal to win the Premier League title. Henry also expressed doubts about Olivier Giroud's ability to lead Arsenal to the title, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. Henry used Chelsea's recent signings as an example of how strategic transfers can lead to league success. Arsenal is currently third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman testified in court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the boss of Bega Cheese. Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim expressed fear for her future relationships and felt that Van Ryn had stolen her right to share her body with someone for the first time. She did not understand the abuse was wrong as a child and only spoke up after learning Van Ryn had been caught. Since then, she has struggled with depression, self-harm, and suicidal thoughts, and worries about Van Ryn's future release and its impact on her life.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is nearing a return to action after recovering from a serious knee injury that has kept him out for over a year. He played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading and expressed feeling 'better and better' as he looks forward to his next game. Gnabry impressed for Arsenal last season before his injury.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling down a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while trying to avoid paying his taxi fare. Phillips, who was out drinking with friends, ran from the taxi driver after realizing he didn't have enough cash to pay. He leapt over a fence in the dark and plunged down the cliff. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, stopped chasing him due to poor visibility and was unaware of the danger Phillips was in. Phillips' body was found the next morning by a dog walker. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating that Phillips was likely disoriented and unaware of the cliff's proximity. Phillips was a graduate from the University of Birmingham and worked for Pretty Green, a clothing label run by Liam Gallagher. He had been staying with his mother in the Cowbridge area for Christmas.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco received no compensation. The passport agency made a £42 million profit during this time, and managers received bonuses up to £3,500. Ministers refused blanket refunds to families who paid extra for rushed passports or missed trips. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, totaling £203,066. The passport office struggled with 3.6 million applications, leading to a backlog of over half a million passports by mid-June.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, is for sale with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. The semi-detached property remains largely unchanged, featuring original stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom, wood-panelled hallway, vintage kitchen cupboards, and retro food jars. The house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as a backup to Alex Smith with the San Francisco 49ers. He became the starter mid-2012 season after Smith's concussion, leading the team to the Super Bowl, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
The passage discusses the 1997 American comedy-drama film "Soul Food." It was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and it was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and lived there for much of her early life before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast via the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, born and raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed the band Blur. Blur's debut album, "Leisure," was released in 1991. The band's self-titled album in 2001 achieved worldwide success. Albarn's debut solo album, "Everyday Robots," was released in 2014, featuring collaborations with notable artists and sampling Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It is home to many important national institutions.

The passage discusses a song titled "Happiness in Slavery" by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails. This song is featured on their debut extended play (EP) album, "Broken," which was released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The passage discusses two works titled "Shooter":

1. **Shooter (2007 film)**: This film features Mark Wahlberg as Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran who is falsely accused of murder by a corrupt private military company.

2. **Shooter (TV series)**: This series stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action to thwart a plot to assassinate the president.
"House, M.D." is an American medical drama television series that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, which were carried out by his group. He was also convicted for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After his arrest, his songs were released commercially.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist born on August 17, 1960. He started his acting career in television in 1974 and made his film debut in 1981. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, he played diverse roles in films like "Fast Times at Ridgemont High," "At Close Range," "State of Grace," and "Carlito's Way." Penn gained significant critical acclaim for his role in "Dead Man Walking" (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination. He won his first Oscar for "Mystic River" (2003) and a second for "Milk" (2008), with additional nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" (1999) and "I Am Sam" (2001).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman (1908-2001), known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After his retirement, he continued to influence the sport as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.

L.A. Reid has held several high-level positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records (Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer known for his work with the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-2011) and Audioslave (2001-2007). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. As of 2016, he is a member of the band Prophets of Rage.

"The Millers" is a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning 34 episodes over two seasons. The show was canceled on November 14, 2014, during its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933 – September 13, 2006) was an American politician who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She was a Democrat who gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas when she delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her outspoken feminism and witty one-liners. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush.
Drake Bell released an EP titled "A Reminder" independently in 2011.

The passage discusses two main topics:

1. **Boardwalk**: A 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, and directed by Verona.

2. **Janet Leigh**: An American actress, singer, dancer, and author. She was born Jeanette Helen Morrison on July 6, 1927, and passed away on October 3, 2004. She also wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader born on July 24, 1783, and died on December 17, 1830. He was instrumental in helping establish Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent sovereign states, free from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is an area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly vanished under unexplained conditions.

Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as a backup to Alex Smith with the San Francisco 49ers. He became the starter mid-2012 season after Smith's concussion, leading the team to the Super Bowl, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, but they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses openly sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote products, services, or ideas through mass media. It differs from personal selling as it is not directed to a particular individual. Media used for advertising include old media like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, or direct mail, and new media such as search results, blogs, websites, or text messages.

The passage discusses two works titled "Private Lives":

1. A 1930 comedy of manners play in three acts written by Noël Coward.
2. A 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice, around 384 BC. He studied at Plato's Academy in Athens from around age 17 until 347 BC. After Plato's death, he tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon, starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer who transitioned into various roles including musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and is currently the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning five championships, including one in his rookie year. He was drafted first overall in 1979 and retired three times, the last in 1996. Johnson is also a notable businessman, recognized by Ebony magazine in 2009, and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: "Tenacious D" (2001), "The Pick of Destiny" (2006), and "Rize of the Fenix" (2012). The band gained initial popularity in 1997 through their self-titled television series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I, born James Stuart, was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death in 1625. He ruled Scotland and England as separate sovereign states in a personal union. He advocated for a single parliament for both countries, achieving some success in Scotland but facing significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and ongoing conflicts with the English Parliament.

The passage discusses the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality television show Big Brother, titled Big Brother 2017 or Big Brother 18. The show is hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley, born on October 4, 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist known for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since 2000. He left Channel 4 in July 2011 to continue narrating Big Brother on Channel 5. Bentley's distinctive Geordie accent has made him one of Britain's most recognized voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering several other German states, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest and sixth most populous state in Germany, with an area of 18,413 km2 and a population of 4 million people. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is known for its wine region, which is one of the northernmost in Europe and one of two in the former East Germany.

The passage discusses two unrelated topics:

1. **East End Park**: A former major league baseball park situated in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati, USA.
2. **In the End**: A song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B, also known as Melanie Brown, started her solo music career by releasing the song "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

"Mohra" is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. The film was released on July 1, 1994, and became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year. It received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was cast in the female lead but was replaced by Raveena Tandon after her death. The film is also noted for its popular songs.

The passage discusses two different musical works:

1. "Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure.
2. "Hourglass" is also the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black, born on December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is recognized for writing the 1987 action film "Lethal Weapon" and for his directorial debut with the 2005 film "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang."
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth film in the James Bond series and the seventh and final one starring Roger Moore as James Bond.

Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, covering most of western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya, and before that, West Irian or Irian Barat, and it encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died from natural causes, with unconfirmed rumors suggesting his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez began her music career in 1999 with the album "On the 6" and the hit single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she achieved a milestone by having a number one album ("J.Lo") and film ("The Wedding Planner") in the same week. Her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her 2002 album "This Is Me... Then" but overshadowed the film "Gigli." She married Marc Anthony, and had twins in 2008. After a period of lesser success, Lopez returned to prominence in 2011 with her role on "American Idol" and the hit single "On the Floor."

Working animals are typically domesticated and trained by humans to perform various tasks. These tasks can range from providing assistance, like guide dogs, to offering tractive force, such as draft horses or logging elephants. They may also be used for milking or herding, requiring human training for cooperation. Wild animals can occasionally be trained for work, but they often lack the trustworthiness and mild temperament of domesticated working animals.

   - **Top Latin Albums**: A record chart published by Billboard magazine, considered the most important for Spanish-language, full-length albums in the American music market.

The passage describes a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film titled "Vedam," directed and written by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. The film features an ensemble cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
"Men in Black II" (MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a character in Miguel de Cervantes' 1605 novel "Don Quixote," serving as the squire to the title character. He is known for his humorous and witty comments, called "sanchismos," which often include ironic Spanish proverbs and earthy wisdom.
"The Adventures of Pluto Nash" is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film. It stars Eddie Murphy in a dual role and is directed by Ron Underwood.
Hedda Gabler is a play by Henrik Ibsen. The world premiere of the play took place on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company located in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born on 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club, commonly known as Juve, is an Italian professional football club based in Turin, founded in 1897 by young students, including Eugenio and Enrico Canfari. It is the second oldest active football club in Italy, after Genoa. The club is known for its black and white striped home kit, which it has worn since 1903, and plays its home matches at the Juventus Stadium, which has a capacity of 41,507.

The Freeport Doctrine was presented by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. Homer is credited by the ancient Greeks as the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two foundational epic poems in ancient Greek literature. Joe R. Lansdale is the author of the mystery/suspense novel The Thicket.

Speech recognition (SR) is a field that combines computational linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to develop technologies that convert spoken language into text. Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of al-Wefaq, spoke to the BBC about the political situation in Bahrain. He emphasized the need for meaningful national dialogue, requiring the government to offer concrete solutions and have a representative from the royal family. He highlighted the division within the court, with hardliners opposed to dialogue and reformists, like Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, open to it. Sheikh Salman acknowledged the distrust of young protesters but believed in working with reformists within the royal family. He also criticized the US and UK governments for not doing enough to pressure Bahrain for human rights and democratic practices. Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a several-month illness. He was known for founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he directed for 30 years across six continents, and for his influential recordings, including a notable version of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various academic and artistic positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and tutor at Harvard University. The passage discusses homicide statistics in Scotland for the year ending March 2016. Key points include:

- 57 homicide victims were recorded, the lowest number since 1976 and half the figure from nine years prior.
- Only one case from 2015-16 was unresolved as of March 31, 2016.
- Sharp instruments, primarily knives, were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides.
- 31% of accused individuals were under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
- Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts to reduce violent crime and support at-risk communities.
- Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker cautioned against over-reliance on the downward trend, citing revisions in previous years' data and increases in other types of crime.

Bournemouth (nicknamed "The Cherries") lost 2-1 to Sunderland in a Premier League match. Dan Gosling scored their first goal in three games. The passage discusses Australia's immigration policy under Prime Minister Tony Abbott, which involves detaining migrants trying to reach the country by boat and processing them offshore. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and of "dubious legality." Abbott maintained that the policy has stopped deaths at sea. The passage discusses the escalating conflict in Aleppo, Syria. Key points include:

- The US blames Russia and the Syrian government for intensified attacks on civilians and suspends talks with Russia due to continued bombing in Aleppo.
- Russia regrets the US decision and accuses the US of shifting blame for the collapse of a recent truce.
- Aleppo has been under heavy bombardment, with hundreds of deaths and a main trauma hospital hit multiple times.
- The US accuses Russia and Syrian forces of targeting critical infrastructure and hindering humanitarian aid.
- Russia denies involvement in a deadly aid convoy strike and criticizes the US for not fulfilling agreements to improve humanitarian conditions.
- The US withdraws personnel involved in potential joint operations with Russia but maintains communication on counter-terrorism efforts.

The passage discusses a proposal by the think tank Policy Exchange to sell high-value vacant social homes to raise funds for building new social housing. Key points include:

- Selling high-value vacant homes could raise £4.5bn a year, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes.
- The proposal aims to create the largest social house building programme since the 1970s.
- Critics, including the Labour Party, argue that this could displace low-income families from affluent areas.
- Policy Exchange suggests that the overall number of people waiting for social housing could be reduced by about 500,000.
- The government supports councils choosing to sell high-value housing to invest in more social housing.
- Labour proposes using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes instead.
- Expensive social housing accounts for 21.8% of the total social housing stock in the UK, which could raise up to £159bn if sold.
- Critics worry about the potential for creating segregated communities and displacing lower-income families.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died last week, with an inquest to be opened and adjourned on Tuesday. He was treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital and later developed a rash. He was found dead the day after seeing an out-of-hours GP. The cause of death is not yet determined, but laboratory tests confirmed a measles diagnosis. The family is unsure how he contracted measles, as no close family members have it. The measles outbreak in Swansea has reached 942 cases, with 83 people needing hospital treatment since November.
Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with a historical offense against a boy under 16, which allegedly occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Cuadrilla suspended shale gas drilling (fracking) in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude earthquake, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is analyzing the data, and Cuadrilla will decide on further actions after consulting with experts. The process is controversial due to environmental concerns, but the UK's energy select committee supports it with proper regulation. The BGS confirmed that both earthquakes were likely caused by fracking and occurred near the drilling site.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing the bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner in April 2015, despite denying three counts. He was acquitted of the other two counts. Carpenter claimed he was busking, not collecting funds for the charity, and had permission to display the banner as a tribute. Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers (QPR) 3-0. Grant Ward scored the first goal with a shot put, Luke Varney scored the second after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance, and Tom Lawrence scored the third. Wells, a 23-year-old player, had a notable performance in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the club's direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches, which motivates the team.

A 28-year-old man named Nazrul, also known as Nazu, is accused of raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town. He was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata. Two incidents occurred in which individuals, posing as BT employees, tricked women into giving them remote access to their computers and stole money. A UN conference in Geneva decided to allocate part of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system using satellites. This decision was prompted by the disappearance of MH370 in 2014, which highlighted gaps in current air navigation systems. The new system will use automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions to enable real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) are involved in implementing this change, with ICAO setting a deadline of November 2016 for new tracking guidelines.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, was found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby was arrested and held at Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on charges related to his son's disappearance and tampering with records. The FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children confirmed Julian's identity after a tip in October. Julian's mother has been notified.

**Concise Summary:**

- A fire on 2 March at a site on Duncan Street, operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited and run by Asset and Land Group, caused travel delays and reduced train services.
- The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the site from accepting waste and later decided to revoke its environmental permit, effective 7 August, due to fire safety concerns.
- Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the site nine times in the past year and found the operators to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws.
- The fire service had raised concerns about potential fire impacts on residents, transport, and the environment.
- The cause of the fire is still undetermined.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia in response to the situation in Ukraine:

1. **Territorial Integration Bill**: This bill aims to simplify the process for integrating new territories into Russia.
