Eugene previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF was persuaded by a recent presentation from Eugene. IAAF president Lamine Diack highlighted the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the enthusiastic public as key factors in the decision. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger targeted Hassan after seeing him with a large amount of cash at a London casino. She befriended him, and he showered her with gifts and cash. On the night of the murder, Granger left Hassan's flat unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, to enter. They tied up and kicked Hassan to death while ransacking his home. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not murder. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 36 years. All three were also convicted of robbing Hassan and conspiring to falsely imprison him.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season, both in club and international matches. Despite a strong start to the season, his form has declined, and he was criticized for his performance in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland. Fabregas has been playing almost every minute for Chelsea, which has led to fatigue. His assist record, which was on track to break Thierry Henry's Premier League record, has slowed down significantly. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is hoping Fabregas can regain his form to help secure the Premier League title.

West Ham is in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United, who impressed during a two-week trial. Beckford, considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean, has also drawn interest from Belgian clubs. Additionally, West Ham has announced that season tickets for their new home at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, aiming to have the lowest pricing in the Premier League to attract fans.

Police have dropped an investigation into a violent assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, despite having evidence, including a video and names of suspected saboteurs. Lane was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters with iron bars while on a hunt with an artificial scent. He suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. The attack occurred in Everleigh, near Amesbury, on January 24. Police issued a suspect's photograph but have not identified anyone. Lane and other hunt supporters are frustrated with the police's decision to shelve the inquiry due to insufficient evidence. Wiltshire Police confirmed they stopped the investigation but will reopen it if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, known as the "American mouthpiece of al Qaeda," was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January 2016. Born in 1978, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and joined al Qaeda in 1998. He became a prominent member, known for his English-language propaganda videos threatening attacks on the U.S. and other countries. Gadahn was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda. He was killed in a U.S. operation in January 2016, along with another U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq.

The passage discusses the phenomenon of Chinese parents nurturing child prodigies, highlighting a viral video of a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo who exhibits remarkable basketball skills. Mai, who has been playing since he was two and a half, impresses viewers with his ability to score hoops and dribble two basketballs simultaneously. His talents have garnered him widespread admiration in China, a country passionate about basketball, particularly after the success of Yao Ming. Netizens express awe and disbelief at Mai's abilities, with some even questioning if the video is real.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which advocated for legalizing child sex in the 1970s and 80s, attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25. The rally, chaired by John Cleese, aimed to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, a media pressure group formed after the phone-hacking scandal, seeks to replace the Independent Press Standards Organisation with a statutory regulatory body, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's involvement with Hacked Off is likely to be controversial due to his past associations.

The passage describes an event where the pool at Bondi's Icebergs Club was drained to serve as a catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event featured a presentation by the label 'ten pieces', which is headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss. The collection consisted of ten unisex pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for both day and night. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. Guests enjoyed food and drinks while watching the show, and passersby also stopped to observe the event. The weather was unusually warm and sunny.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent a family day at a safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa. They interacted with various animals, including feeding a rare white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, dismissing speculations about other potential opponents.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was included on an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl, Jerusalem, commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His name was added as Israel prepared for its Memorial Day. Abu Khdeir, 16, was killed in July by three Israelis. His family and an organization called Almagor, which supports victims of terror, objected to his inclusion, stating that he was not a victim of terrorism but rather a victim of a rogue attack. Following complaints, particularly from Abu Khdeir's father, the National Insurance Institute of Israel decided to remove his name from the memorial.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son trying to use the family cat as a pillow. The footage shows the boy repeatedly lying on the cat, who moves away each time. Eventually, the cat leaves, but later, they are seen reconciling with the boy feeding the cat treats.

The passage discusses a police corruption trial in Philadelphia where a witness, Robert Kushner, has lost his coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. Kushner, one of several former drug dealers testifying against the police, claimed that some undercover officers stole money and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Despite passing a background check when hired in 2010, Kushner's past came to light during his testimony. He had been arrested again in 2011 and pleaded guilty to DUI in 2008. Kushner expressed remorse and maintained his innocence regarding the 2011 charges. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of various crimes, including racketeering.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China, injured six people and sparked a large fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a chemical used in polyester production. The blast, caused by an oil leak, did not result in a reported toxic chemical spill. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze. Residents nearby reported hearing the explosion and feeling tremors. The plant has a history of protests due to pollution concerns and had been previously planned for Xiamen before relocation.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player, is known for wearing his socks low and using children's shinpads due to superstition. He has received comments from referees about his sock and shinpad choices, but he has no intention of changing his ways. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR. He acknowledged the challenge of the game but was pleased to have made his debut.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive despite no longer being in a medically induced coma. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, expressed sadness over her granddaughter's condition, which has remained unchanged for nearly three months. Bobby Brown had previously stated that his daughter's condition had improved, but an attorney for the family clarified that while she is embarking on a long rehabilitation process, the quality of her life remains uncertain.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie, with Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saving a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki, and Svetlana Kuznetsova winning her match against Julia Goerges in straight sets. Russia needs one more win on Sunday to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm, potentially an east coast low, is predicted to hit later this week, bringing heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is still dealing with over 4,000 jobs from the previous week's storms and is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts, particularly in the hard-hit Hunter region. Meteorologists expect the heaviest rain in the far northern parts of the state, with the weather system moving quickly and potentially bringing two days of rain. The Bureau of Meteorology indicates that the main impacts will be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, with heavy falls also likely for southeast Queensland.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" video, addressed rumors about a suicide attempt. Italian media reported that she was found by her mother in their Milan apartment and had tried to take her own life. However, Moric denied these claims on Instagram, stating that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure after collapsing at home. She posted photos of her injuries and assured her followers that she was recovering well. Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, initially suggested that she had attempted suicide, but Moric clarified that he was in Naples at the time of the incident. Moric also mentioned that she was once married to Fabrizio Corona, a famous paparazzi who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

Prince William and Kate are expecting their second child, and the British public hopes they will choose a traditional name. A YouGov poll for The Sunday Times found that if the baby is a girl, 12% of respondents favor the name Diana, after William's mother, Princess Diana. Other popular names for a girl include Alice and Charlotte. If the baby is a boy, 13% prefer James, with Alexander being the second favorite. Many people hope for a girl, with a quarter of the 2,200 polled wanting a female baby. The public also supports William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave, with 68% approving. Social media users have expressed their desire for the baby to be named Diana if it is a girl.

A suicide bomber targeted protesters in eastern Afghanistan, near the city of Khost, killing 17 people and injuring 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time. The Taliban denied involvement, and no other group has claimed responsibility. The protesters were en route to a rally against the provincial governor.

Dani Alves, a Brazilian right-back, is leaving Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. He spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies. Alves' agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that he had rejected a three-year contract extension due to the conditions.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old player at Boca Juniors, has suggested that Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti should join him at the Argentine club. Osvaldo, who has been successful since joining Boca on loan from Southampton, believes that Pirlo and Totti's playing styles would be well-suited to Boca Juniors and that the fans would enthusiastically welcome them. Pirlo is renowned as one of the world's top midfielders, while Totti is a legendary figure at Roma.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular fall during a race at Wincanton, performing a double somersault after being thrown from his horse, Merrion Square. The incident, which occurred in the 4.20 pm race, has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. Ferguson sustained only a minor cut on his nose and was back to his regular duties at Paul Nicholls' yard the following morning. He described the fall as a blur and expressed gratitude for his luck, noting that he received support from fellow jockeys and some good-natured teasing. Despite the incident, Ferguson remains undeterred and is considering a potential career in gymnastics.

**Concise Summary:**

- The passage discusses James Haskell, a rugby player, who posted an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man to celebrate the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron."
- The movie premiered in London, with a cast including Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson.
- Haskell, the captain of London Wasps, has had a varied rugby career, playing in England, France, Japan, and New Zealand.
- He first joined Wasps in 2002, left in 2009, and returned in 2012. Since his return, he has made over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the trend of wide-leg trousers for the spring/summer 2015 season. Key points include:

- Wide-leg trousers are a prominent trend, available in various styles like denim, cropped, printed, or striped.
- This trend offers an alternative to the popular skinny jeans.
- The wide-leg look has made comebacks since the 1970s.
- Styling tips include wearing high heels to elongate the legs and pairing with simple tops to maintain proportion.
- Denim is highlighted as an easy way to adopt this trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering denim wide-leg options.
- Designer brands like Celine and Stella McCartney showcased dressier wide-leg styles.
- The trend is versatile and can be worn in various settings, including evenings.
- The trend is accessible at different price points, with options from high-end designers to more affordable online labels like Finery London.

The University of Michigan initially faced objections from over 200 students who signed a petition against screening "American Sniper" due to concerns about its portrayal of the Iraq War and the Middle East. However, after a backlash and a counter-petition, the university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, announced that the screening would proceed. The decision was made to uphold the university's commitment to freedom of expression and student choice. An alternative family-friendly film, "Paddington," will also be offered. The university's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh, praised the decision.

A quokka on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, was targeted in a cruel act by two French tourists on April 3. The men allegedly set an aerosol spray alight with a lighter, causing a flame to singe the quokka. The animal survived, and the men were questioned by detectives, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty. They are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, similar in size to domestic cats, are found on small islands off the Western Australian coast, including Rottnest Island.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer in 1930s and 1940s New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar, had never seen footage of herself dancing or her memorabilia. With the help of filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers, she was shown a video of "soundies" (early music videos) featuring her performances. Barker was delighted to see herself dancing again.

The passage discusses the decline in the practice of washing one's own car in Britain. Key points include:

- A third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own car.
- Only 12% of men who do wash their cars do so regularly.
- Factors contributing to this decline include the rise of hand car washes, larger vehicle sizes, and changes in weekend activities.
- Car washing is more common during holidays, with an estimated 15 million cars cleaned by owners during the recent Easter break.
- Regional and vehicle-specific trends are noted, with certain cities and car brands more likely to be washed by their owners.
- The decline is attributed to time constraints, larger vehicles, and the availability of affordable car washing services.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard's impact on him and Liverpool since Gerrard's arrival in 2008. Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with a potential final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30, before joining LA Galaxy. Skrtel, who joined Liverpool in 2008, credits Gerrard for helping him settle at the club. Despite Gerrard's impending departure, Skrtel believes Liverpool has potential replacements and can overcome the challenge of filling his void. Both players may return for the Villa match after serving suspensions.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus achieved a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was his first ace at Augusta, but it was eclipsed by Camilo Villegas, who made two holes-in-one that day. Nicklaus, who won the Masters six times, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

**Concise Summary:**

- **Event:** Tornado sirens activated in Kansas due to multiple storms and reported twisters.
- **Locations Affected:**
  - Kansas: Near Goddard (northwest of Wichita) and southwestern Kansas (near Aetna).
  - Missouri: Potosi (near St. Louis) with reports of wind damage, flooding, and a possible tornado.
  - Other areas in Missouri and Illinois reported hail and unusual clouds.
- **Expert Insight:** CNN's Chad Myers warned about the danger of nighttime tornadoes.
- **Forecast:** More storms expected on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. The judge allowed Bates to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which drew criticism from Harris' family. Bates, 73, was involved in Harris' arrest during a weapons sting operation on April 2. The lawyer for Harris' family claims Bates was not qualified to be on the force and received preferential treatment. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these allegations. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11. He recently got a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, with the caption "if you see the tiger, it's too late. you're food." McGregor believes he has more motivation to win the title than Aldo does to defend it. The two have a contentious relationship, and McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was cheered by a crowd of about 50 as he quickly drank a schooner of beer at an Australian rules function. This action drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners, who argued that he was glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with excessive alcohol consumption. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert stated that this behavior sets a problematic culture where drinking is about quantity and speed rather than socializing. Abbott was asked to drink by a coach, and it took him about six seconds to finish the beer. Critics, including the opposition leader Bill Shorten, and health minister Sussan Ley, had differing reactions to the incident. While some defended Abbott's actions, others, like Robert, expressed concern about the message it sends, especially given the shift in attitudes towards binge drinking.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, primarily due to intravenous drug use involving the painkiller Opana. Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program to combat the outbreak, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants. The program's future is uncertain, as Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy. Legislation to allow needle-exchange programs in other counties is under consideration, but faces opposition and funding challenges.

An Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a comprehensive test about the football club. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables, and essay sections, and was marked with a red pen. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), impressing her boyfriend enough to avoid being "dumped." She shared the experience on Twitter, where it received mixed reactions. Some praised the boyfriend as a "legend" and Saskia for her knowledge, while others thought he had taken things too far. The test included questions about Arsenal's history, players, and even a comparison between Alexis Sánchez and Eden Hazard. Saskia's creative answers, such as describing Sánchez as "buff" and Hazard as a "p***k," earned her extra points. Despite some mistakes, like confusing player positions, she passed with an 'A' grade.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for promised U.S. citizenship. He aided in the prosecution of notable figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, Toro is now facing deportation due to declining health and retirement. The DEA has not assisted him with citizenship, and he fears for his life if returned to Colombia. Toro is currently in limbo, unable to secure a green card or passport, and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

A 14-year-old girl in India allegedly set herself on fire after being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is currently in critical condition with 70% burns at Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital. The incident occurred in Kosi Kalan, Mathura district, Uttar Pradesh, when she went outside to relieve herself. Her family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. The accused men have been arrested. This incident comes amidst heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following recent high-profile cases and protests.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is eager to beat rivals Manchester City in their upcoming derby at Old Trafford but will be without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw due to fitness concerns. Van Gaal believes a win could secure a top-three finish and Champions League qualification. He acknowledges City will be a tough opponent but hopes his team has learned from their previous loss. The team trained in good spirits ahead of the match, with key players like Wayne Rooney, Angel Di Maria, and Radamel Falcao participating. Van Gaal appreciates the support of the United fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was organized in response to the £5.14 billion TV rights deal and the high cost of tickets, with the cheapest tickets starting at £64. Fans from both clubs displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, with messages such as '£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket' and 'football without fans is nothing'. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups, with supporters calling for tangible reductions in ticket prices to make football more accessible to working-class fans.

A newborn baby named Star, diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth, underwent a life-saving liver transplant from her maternal aunt, Shanell, who is the twin sister of Star's mother, Jade. The condition, which affects about 1 in 16,000 babies, involves blocked or absent bile ducts and can be fatal if untreated. Star's parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, noticed her skin turning yellow shortly after birth, leading to a diagnosis of jaundice and subsequent liver tests. After an unsuccessful attempt to unclog her bile ducts, a liver transplant became necessary. Neither parent was a suitable match, but Shanell offered part of her liver, saving Star's life. Star underwent the operation in November and has since made a good recovery, requiring weekly blood tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. Hazard and Ake teamed up against Remy and Willian. In the first round, Hazard and Ake won 5-3 by scoring into the boot of a car from close range. In the second round, they won again by playing over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus, taking a 6-0 lead. In the final challenge, Remy and Willian won by scoring from long range into a convertible Audi, but Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, 54, from New Hampshire, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy (24, eight months pregnant) and her fiancé Jason Timmons (29), and their unborn baby. Dellinger drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100 mph and collided with the couple's SUV. During his sentencing on Wednesday, Dellinger stated he was not suicidal at the time of the crash. Prosecutors had previously reported that Dellinger told investigators he was attempting suicide. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus's death and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. His wife, Deborah Dellinger, described him as a man of integrity and ethics. The crash occurred due to Dellinger's alleged struggle with medication withdrawal and health issues.

Lacey Spears, of Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt. She was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and hope that she would die in prison on Facebook. Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill to gain attention, while her lawyer claimed she was a hardworking single mother who loved her son. Spears' lawyer plans to appeal the verdict.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against two new strains (H3N2 and B/Phuket) that caused a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine's arrival is delayed by a month due to these additions. High-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and most indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots from April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, recommend that everyone get vaccinated, as the new vaccine also protects against the H1N1 strain. Dr. Hampson advises people to book their flu shots now due to the delay and to help protect high-risk individuals.

The passage discusses the current situation surrounding Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois. Key points include:

- The caretakers of the tomb are defending against criticism from National Geographic, which described the site as lacking historical character, and facing potential budget cuts proposed by Governor Bruce Rauner.
- The state of Illinois is in a financial crisis, and the governor has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb.
- The tomb has undergone significant renovations totaling over $2.5 million, including repairs to the interior and exterior, as well as waterproofing and landscaping projects.
- Despite the criticism, many visitors and supporters find the tomb impressive and historically significant.
- The tomb was designed by Larkin Mead, dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, and has undergone multiple reconstructions due to foundation issues.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, highlighting both popular and controversial items. Key points include:

- **Popular Trends**: Chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts are currently in vogue.
- **Controversial Comeback**: JNCO jeans, known for their extremely wide legs, are set to make a comeback, much to the dismay of those who wore them in the past.
- **Retro Fashion Trends**:
  - **Bucket Hat**: Originally worn by fishermen and farmers, it became popular in the 1990s and early 2000s, with celebrities like Rihanna bringing it back.
  - **Camouflage Print**: Popularized by bands like Destiny's Child in the early 2000s, it is still seen on celebrities like Jordon Dunn.
  - **Extreme Fashion**: Trends like designer prints and double denim were taken to extremes by celebrities in the 1990s and early 2000s, with Kylie Jenner continuing this trend.
  - **UGG Boots**: Popularized by Paris Hilton in the 20

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

- **Weather Event**: Four rainbows appeared in the New York area after heavy rain.
- **China**: The practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes is being restricted due to a crackdown on vice.
- **Celebrity News**: Robert Downey Jr. was agitated during an interview about his private life. The Kardashians have sparked a new lip plumping trend.
- **Entertainment**: Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumière in the live-action 'Beauty and the Beast'. Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer.
- **Viral Stories**: A 102-year-old woman went back in time with the help of filmmakers. A prom proposal referencing bombs sparked controversy. A military dad photobombed his son's photo.
- **Pregnancy Announcement**: A unique pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'.

Serena Williams secured her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, receiving a giant cake in celebration. She advanced to the semi-finals after defeating Sabine Lisicki. Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals, as Halep beat Sloane Stephens. Andy Murray also recently celebrated his 500th career win with a cake.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and founder of the Second Floor Cafe (T2F) in Karachi, was shot and killed by two gunmen after hosting a discussion on human rights and the Balochistan conflict. She was known for her advocacy of free speech, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, and had received death threats in the past. Her cafe was a hub for progressive discussions and secular wisdom. Mahmud's death sparked an outpouring of grief and tributes from those who admired her courage and advocacy for progressive values. The motive behind her killing remains unclear, and no one has claimed responsibility.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, fled to Indian Kashmir as a refugee during the 1947 partition of India and has since been denied citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote in state elections. Around 100,000 people, known as West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), share a similar fate, living in poverty in India's only Muslim-majority state. The success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party in a recent state vote has given Ram and others hope that their refugee status may finally change. The BJP, which has joined the Kashmir governing coalition, is expected to champion the WPRs' cause. However, successive governments have been reluctant to grant full rights to the WPRs due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance between Muslim and Hindu populations. Activists like Labha Ram Gandhi argue that granting state-subject rights is the only way to improve the WPRs' condition, and the community is prepared to take action if their hopes are not met.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering a move to Chelsea, who have made an offer of around £4 million for him. Muto is keen to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Chelsea plans to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem if he joins. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, believes Muto has great potential and could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea's manager, Jose Mourinho, is aware of Muto and acknowledges that commercial interests play a part in the club's transfer policy.

The passage discusses the policy of selecting national rugby teams, focusing on Australia and England. Australia has changed its policy to allow the selection of their best players, regardless of whether they play overseas. This contrasts with England's policy, which currently excludes players based overseas. The author argues that England should follow Australia's lead and select the best available players, citing examples like Matt Giteau, Drew Mitchell, Steffon Armitage, and Nick Abendanon, who have improved their games while playing overseas. The author emphasizes that selecting the best team is crucial for England's success in the upcoming World Cup, especially as the host nation. The passage also mentions that clubs benefit from a winning national team and that the Rugby Football Union (RFU) or Premier Rugby should not dictate player selection.

The passage discusses the FireChat app and the Greenstone device developed by Open Garden. FireChat allows users to chat with friends without needing web or mobile signals by creating wireless mesh networks using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) or similar Android features. This app has been downloaded over five million times and is useful in areas without signal, like planes or underground. However, the range of these networks is limited to around 200 feet. Greenstone is an egg-shaped device designed to boost these networks, extending the range and making off-the-grid communication more resilient. It acts as a beacon, holding up to 1,000 recent messages until another FireChat user comes within range. Greenstone is still under development and currently works with FireChat at a range of around 20 feet, with a one-year battery life.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, aims to redefine the word 'fat' as a neutral, body-positive descriptor. In her 2014 TED talk, she shared her perspective that 'fat' should not be synonymous with 'ugly' and that women are often conditioned to avoid the term. Bustle, who is 5'3" and 240 lbs, uses words like'short' and 'wife' to describe herself honestly, and she encourages others to do the same with 'fat'. She notes that size discrimination has increased and that negative body perceptions start young. However, she finds hope in studies showing that exposure to body diversity fosters acceptance and tolerance. Bustle's burlesque performances expose audiences to a positive, glamorous image of a 'fat' body, challenging societal norms. Her first performance in 2012 was empowering, and she encourages others to find a 'courage reference' to boost self-esteem. Despite some negative comments, her TED talk has received mostly positive feedback, with many viewers appreciating her message.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has spent most of the season on the bench, being overlooked for the majority of the games. He, along with six of his Arsenal colleagues (Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil), participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor. Walcott has been named as a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games. He came on for the last six minutes of Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea. Walcott is hoping to make his first Arsenal start since March 14 when they face Hull City. Arsenal's first team will be dressed in Lanvin attire for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa.

A collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on Propstore.com. The collection, valued at $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions, such as "Men in Black," "Batman Forever," and "How the Grinch Stole Christmas." Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from "Men in Black" ($40,000), the Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" ($8,000), and the Two-Face mask from "Batman Forever" ($1,500). The auction features 417 original items, with some expected to sell for much more than their estimated values.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died in the French Alps after falling over a 164ft drop while skiing with his family. He was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster. Carwyn became separated from his mother and ventured into dense woodland, where he tragically fell. His family expressed their devastation, describing him as a loving and lively person who brought laughter into their lives. Carwyn was a competent skier and snowboarder, and his family had been enjoying a happy ski holiday in Flaine before the incident. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. The family is from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales and are well-known in their community.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 due to pressures to be a "size zero." She survived on minimal food, hiding it from her parents and lying about eating. Her condition worsened, leading to a collapse and hospitalization. Laura's dramatic weight loss was due to an obsession with her figure, exacerbated by bullying and societal pressures. She was hospitalized for a week on a heart monitor and later received support from eating disorder organizations. Laura's mother, Sue, also noted the intense pressure on young girls to maintain a certain appearance. Laura has since recovered and reached the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive body image.

Liverpool unveiled their new home kit for the 2015/16 season, designed by New Balance, who signed a £300 million four-year deal to replace Warrior as the club's suppliers. The kit was presented by players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet. Liverpool fans expressed their desire for Sterling to stay at the club amid rumors of his potential departure. Sterling, who rejected a £100,000-a-week contract offer, was urged by fans to remain at Liverpool. The new kit features an all-white branding with a new collar style and a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims. The club is focused on the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with players emphasizing the importance of fan support.

The passage discusses a high-definition map of dark matter created by researchers at the University of Manchester. Here are the core pieces of information:

- **Map Details**: The map covers 0.4% of the sky and shows clumps of dark matter, with red indicating more dark matter and blue indicating less. It was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile.
- **Purpose**: The map aims to study galaxy formation and understand the distribution of dark matter, which makes up at least 80% of the matter in the universe. The ultimate goal is to map 12.5% of the sky over five years as part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES).
- **Method**: The map was created by measuring the shapes of galaxies and using gravitational lensing to infer the presence of dark matter.
- **Significance**: The map supports current cosmological theories that galaxies form where there are large concentrations of dark matter. It also aims to probe the nature of dark energy, which is causing the universe's expansion to accelerate.
- **Future Plans**: The survey will continue to expand its search, allowing scientists to better test cosmological theories and understand the interplay of mass and light. The survey will

Manchester United has officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old Memphis Depay. The player is a Dutch international and has been impressive this season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games. Louis van Gaal, the Manchester United manager, is keen to sign Depay, having previously managed him during the 2014 World Cup. PSV has confirmed the interest from Manchester United, as well as from other top European clubs like Paris Saint-Germain. Depay is known for his pace, close control, and ability to dribble, and has been compared to players like Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team at the Academy Stadium. Tammy Abraham scored two goals in the first half, and Dominic Solanke added a late goal. Key performers for Chelsea included Abraham, Solanke, Charlie Colkett, and Jake Clarke-Salter. For Manchester City, notable players were Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, who scored City's goal, and Brandon Barker, who was City's standout player. Chelsea's defense, featuring Fikayo Tomori and Jay Dasilva, was particularly strong.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, has stated that people are born with a sexual preference, but he believes that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that states should decide on the definition of marriage. He would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he doesn't agree with it. Rubio, a Catholic, also noted that he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. He has announced his candidacy for president and has received significant financial backing.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple cycling around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They quit their jobs in Manchester and have been traveling for about a year, covering nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They live on less than three euros each per day, relying on free accommodation and camping, and their only major expense is food. They started in London, traveled through Europe, and are now in Asia, planning to continue across the Pacific and through the Americas.

A Texas couple who got married in 2012 is suing their photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on photo booth pictures from their wedding. The couple, who wish to remain anonymous, was not aware of the incident until months after the wedding. The photographer has denied the allegations and has not apologized. The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. The wedding was held at the Beautiful Bell Tower in northwest Houston. The couple's lawyer, Cathy Hale, stated that they primarily seek an apology. Mediation is scheduled, but a trial is set for July if no agreement is reached.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, which occurred during a match against Italy. He is unsure when he will return to action for his club side, Harlequins. Brown has been advised to avoid rushing his recovery to prevent extended breaks from the game. He was knocked out during the match against Italy and pulled out of the subsequent game against Ireland due to concussion symptoms. He has been advised to avoid rushing his recovery to prevent extended breaks from the game. George North, a Northampton wing, has been advised not to play again this season after suffering four quick-fire concussions. Johnny Sexton, an Ireland player, was stood down for 12 weeks earlier this term due to concussion. Brown's increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby online modules, helped him realize he would not be ready to face Ireland.

The passage discusses a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among British couples, which has been linked to increased smartphone use and internet access. Key points include:

- The average frequency of sex for heterosexual couples has decreased from five times a month in 1990, to four times in 2000, and to three times in recent years.
- Professor David Spiegelhalter from Cambridge University suggests that the integration of public and private lives due to constant connectivity is a significant factor in this decline.
- Other factors mentioned include busier lives, increased time spent alone, and the erosion of boundaries between work and home.
- Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, notes that competing demands on time and constant connectivity can make sex a lower priority.

The passage discusses the dramatic shift in the popularity and treatment of Tibetan Mastiffs in China. Once highly prized and commanding prices up to £1.2 million each, these dogs, known for their loyalty and traditional use in herding, have fallen out of favor due to government anti-corruption measures and bans on owning large dogs in major cities. As a result, many Tibetan Mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in hotpots and their skin for leather. The decline in their status has led to a glut of poor-quality dogs, with some breeders resorting to cross-breeding for profit. Animal welfare workers have rescued groups of these dogs from inhumane conditions, highlighting the cruel fate of many Tibetan Mastiffs in China.

The passage discusses a survey conducted in Paris where every woman surveyed reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment on public transport. Key points include:

- Half of the women surveyed had experienced harassment before the age of 18.
- Harassment ranged from verbal abuse to physical assaults.
- Six out of ten women felt afraid of being attacked on public transport, compared to three out of ten men.
- The harassment often goes unreported and limits women's freedom, altering their daily routines and excluding them from public spaces.
- The survey led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on public transport.
- Experts emphasized the need to educate women and the public about the severity of such acts and the importance of reporting them.

The passage discusses a competition called #everydayfix run by Leeds-based Direct Line, where groups designed products to solve common everyday problems. The top ten everyday emergencies identified in a survey of 2,000 people include issues like not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Three prototypes were shortlisted:

1. **Snooze**: An alarm clock that connects with your phone to silence notifications for a good night's sleep.
2. **Forget Me Lock**: A device that fastens on a key and indicates whether the door is locked (red) or open (green).
3. **Nipper**: A small mobile phone charger that uses any household battery as its energy source.

Voting for the favorite product is open on Twitter, with the winner to be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. Other notable but non-shortlisted products include a smart helmet for cycling, a parking pin, and an app to relay messages when the phone dies.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she co-directs with Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics, including Keith Vaz, have accused them of a conflict of interest and inappropriate use of public funds. Baird has defended her decision, stating that all procedures were followed. The investigation aims to determine if any conflict of interest rules were broken.

Three people have been sentenced to prison for their involvement in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce. The ringleader, Corry "Corey" Campbell, 21, was sentenced to 20 years for the abuse. Campbell believed Valecce had hurt his cat and stolen money and drugs. Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and forcibly tattooed with offensive images over three days in the basement of Campbell's mother's house. Campbell's girlfriend, Sandra Ng, 19, was sentenced to 23 months, and another accomplice, Carl Halin, 18, received the same 20-year sentence as Campbell. Two other individuals, David Thomas, 28, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively. The incident occurred in late March 2014, and Valecce escaped and contacted police on April 1.

Manchester United has officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old Memphis Depay. The player is a top scorer for PSV, with 20 goals in 26 league games this season. United manager Louis van Gaal, who coached Depay during the 2014 World Cup, is eager to sign him. PSV has confirmed United's interest, along with that of Paris Saint-Germain and another European club. Depay, known for his pace, dribbling skills, and shooting ability, has been compared to Arjen Robben and even a young Cristiano Ronaldo by some scouts. He has also been a key player for the Dutch national team, scoring in the 2014 World Cup.
